creator: istvan@site.uottawa.ca
text:
While you admit you did not test running Tomcat with a security manager,
it does not work. In other words, it is not possible to prevent someone
to call System.exit and expect it to be blocked. We are running a server
at the University for graduate students. Well, it would be all great if
they could not sabotage each other's work. Is there a version of Tomcat
where one can specify -secure at the command line and expect this to work
too?

creator: jfarcand@apache.org
text:
Hi,

I don't what you are doing, but the security manager works perfectly as it
should. Please verify your scripts. Doing System.exit(0) certainly doesn't works
when Tomcat is started using catalina run -security.

-- Jeanfrancois

creator: ian_d_stewart@bankone.com
text:
(untested): the -D parameter that sets catalina.profile in catalina.sh uses the
comparison operator (==) instead of the assignment operator.  In theory, this
should present the Catalina profile from being used.  

I'm not familiar enough with either Security Management or java's command-line
processing routines to say exactly what is going on, but I would think that
fixing this would resolve the issues that the original submitter was reporting

creator: funkman@joedog.org
text:
Resolving as works for me based on "Jean-Francois Arcand" comments and lack of
followup to present a test case.

The == is intentional. (I forget why but it was discussed in a tomcat-dev thread)
